_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Winterset Water Utility
  RMP Executive Summary
  
  
  The Winterset Water Utility had adopted the following vision statement in regards not only to
chemical safety,
  but all safety matters:
  
  The personal safety and health of each employee of this organization is of primary importance.
The prevention
  of occupationally induced injuries and illnesses will be given priority over operating productivity
whenever
  necessary. To the greatest degree possible, the Winterset Water Utility will provide all
mechanical and
  physical facilities required for personal safety and health in keeping with the highest standards.
  
  The Water Utility Board of Directors, Supervisory personnel, and employees has committed
themselves to
  safety in all areas of operation with training and policies designed to protect everyone. These
programs
  include, but are not limited to Hazardous Communication (Right-to-Know), Lock-out/Tag-out,
Confined
  Space, Respiratory Protection, PPE and Emergency/Disaster Planning.
  
  
  The Winterset Water Utility (WWU) is engaged in the production of potable (drinking) water
for the
  community of Winterset, Iowa.  The treatment plant is located approximately 1.75 miles NE of
the community.
  
  Its six man staff operates a superpulsator surface water treatment plant under the guidelines of
the Iowa
  Department of Natural Resources. The process treatment flow is as follows:
  
  Oxidation using Potassium Permanganate & Chlorine Dioxide utilizing a baffled mixing,
detention tank.
  
  Flocculation and sedimentation using PAC and polymers for floc formation utilizing both rapid
and slow
  mixers and two superpulsator up flow clarifiers.
  
  Filtration using a dual bed sand and carbon filter. The GAC helps with removal of inorganics,
farm chemicals,
  taste & odor precursors.
  
  Following filtration sodium hydroxide (caustic soda) is added to adjust the pH to control
corrosion in the
  distribution system, hydrofluosilic acid (fluoride) is add

ed for protection against tooth decay and
gas chlorine is
  used for disinfection. 
  
  Chlorine (a regulated substance) is stored in four, 2,000 lb. cylinders in a storage room located
on the SE
  corner of our building.
  
  Using RMP*Comp & Landview software the Winterset Water Utility has determined the
following release
  scenarios:
  
  Worst-Case Release
  
          quantity released - 2,000 lbs in 10 minutes
          area affected - 2.23 miles from release
          population affected - 672
  
  Alternative Release
  
          quantity released - 630 lbs in 60 minutes
          area affected - 0.2 miles from release
          population affected - 7
  
  Both of the above scenarios would be mitigated by the building the chlorine is housed in.
Accidental release is
  unlikely due to training and procedures followed by the Winterset Water Utility staff. These
include, but are
  not limited to:
  
          inspection of cylinders prior to acceptance
          unloading, transfer & storage procedures
          changing of cylinder procedures
          sops for start-up, general operation, shutdown
          availability of safety and leak repair equipment on site
          surrounding topography (hills) should limit release to immediate area
          emergency response & evacuation plan
  
  In addition the Winterset Water Utility follows all rules, regulations & practices for chlorine
safety established
  by  IDNR and EPA.
  
  Although the Winterset Water Utility has never had an chlorine release event,  a emergency plan
has been
  developed in cooperation with the Water Utility, fire department, law enforcement, ambulance,
hospital/clinics,
  County LEPC.
  
  Emergency planning includes:
  
          Evacuation, public warning
          Health related issues
          Injuries
          Repair 
          Clean-up & restoration
  
  Future planning includes:
  
          Continued updating of procedures & employee training.
          Training exercises

such as mock leak and evacuation drills.
          Further notification of evacuation zone, so that they are aware of leak possibilities and can
            make plans of their own.
